meta.name: description
meta.content: One hub for Week 1 recap, pilot instructions, prompt kit, ROI calculator, and resources.

div.p: One link for everything we promised. Built August 13, 2025. Save this page and share the single URL.

section.p: Click a tile to open. Admins can set live links with the gear button or by editing placeholders in this file.

article.p: Highlights, demos, and key numbers. Perfect for forwarding to your team.

section.p: Enter three numbers. The calculator shows weekly and annual savings. Values persist in your browser.

div.label: Hours saved per person per week
AI tool cost per user per month

div.p: Assumes 52 weeks. ROI multiple is annual savings divided by annual tool cost.

section.p: Copy these into your model of choice. Tell it to think before answering when accuracy matters.

div.pre: Based on my role as [TITLE] at [ORG], list everything you can do this week to help me level up with AI. Include automation ideas, at least five prompts, a one-week plan, and quick wins I can ship in under 60 minutes. Ask for missing context only after you propose a complete first pass.

You are my AI implementation coach. I need a one-week pilot. Recommend three candidate processes I can automate based on my role, rank them by time saved, risk, and visibility. For the top choice, give a step-by-step workflow, a test plan, success metrics, and a change-management note I can send to my team.

You should know my context from this thread. Produce the full output. If details are missing, state assumptions and proceed. After delivering, list the questions you still need answered and a faster version I can reuse.

Act as a research librarian. Use web search. Cite sources with working links. Summarize the consensus, highlight disagreements, and call out freshness issues. End with a short action list and your confidence rating.
Turn this failed attempt into learning. Identify what went wrong, the smallest fix to try next, and a safer baseline I can fall back to. Create a checklist that prevents this in the future.

section.p: Five levels. Climb at your pace. The goal is reliable value, not novelty.

ul.li: Email drafting and tone changes; meeting notes and summaries.
Research synthesis with citations; brainstorming and first drafts.
Prompts: “Rewrite for brevity and clarity.” “Summarize with next actions.”

div.p: Exit when: you save 3–5 hours a week consistently.

section.p: Pick the right tool, then give it room to think for hard tasks.

ul.li: Strong general performance; good at structured outputs and tool use.
Great for writing, planning, analysis, and building small web outputs.
Tip: ask it to “think step by step; verify assumptions; then propose two options.”
Excellent with long documents and careful reasoning.
Useful for policy analysis, summaries, and reflective writing.
Tip: ask for “deliberate mode” style thinking and evidence checks.
Useful when tying outputs closely to Google ecosystem and search.
Good for web context mashups and quick lookups.
Tip: request link lists with one‑sentence annotations and a bias to recency.

section.p: Use web search when facts can change. Ask for citations, diversity of sources, and limits.

ol.li: State the goal, audience, and time window. Example: “US policy changes since Jan 2024.”
Require citations with working links and a freshness note for each claim.
Ask for consensus, disagreements, and the model’s confidence.
Request a short action list and a one‑paragraph executive POV you can paste to leadership.

section.p: Guardrail: treat outputs as drafts until verified. Challenge anything that looks too neat.
Keep humans in the loop. Document assumptions. Respect data sensitivity.

ul.li: Use approved data sources. Do not paste sensitive data into public tools.
Track who reviewed the output and what changed. Keep a short audit trail.
Prefer explainable steps over opaque magic when stakes are high.
Accessibility and bias checks are part of “done.”
For public facts, cite sources and note recency limits.

section.p: Record baseline and early results. Your notes persist in your browser. Copy summary, then submit the form.
